state.meetingNotes:
Meeting Notes: Chef I/O Configuration Feature Discussion
Date: 2024-12-22
Attendees: Product Team

---

DISCUSSION SUMMARY:

We need to define where Chef reads input from and where it writes output to. Currently everything is hardcoded - input is a single text file, output goes to ./docs/output/. This limits adoption and flexibility.

KEY DECISIONS:

1. INPUT SOURCES - Where meeting notes come from:
   - Local files (.txt, .md, .docx)
   - Directory scanning (process all files in a folder)
   - Clipboard/stdin (pipe content directly)
   - URLs (fetch from web/wiki)
   - Future: Confluence, Notion, Google Docs APIs

2. OUTPUT DESTINATIONS - Where PBIs are exported:
   - Local markdown files (current behavior)
   - JSON files (for tooling integration)
   - YAML files (for GitOps workflows)
   - stdout (for piping to other tools)
   - Future: Jira, Azure DevOps, GitHub Issues, Linear

3. CONFIGURATION APPROACH:
   - CLI flags for one-off overrides
   - Config file (.chefrc.yaml or chef.config.yaml) for project defaults
   - Environment variables for CI/CD pipelines

ACTION ITEMS:

- Create InputConfig and OutputConfig types in @chef/core
- Add --input-format and --output-dir flags to CLI
- Support config file loading with sensible defaults
- Document supported formats and destinations

RISKS IDENTIFIED:

- Scope creep with too many integrations
- Breaking changes to existing CLI interface
- Authentication complexity for external services

PRIORITY: High - this is foundational for adoption
eventIndicators: Breaking down work into technical components (InputConfig, OutputConfig types)
Discussing acceptance criteria for input/output sources
Identifying scope and technical implementation details
Creating action items for development work
Feature design discussion rather than sprint planning or progress updates

candidates.title: As a Chef user, I want to configure input sources so that I can process meeting notes from various formats and locations
candidates.rawContext: We need to define where Chef reads input from and where it writes output to. Currently everything is hardcoded - input is a single text file, output goes to ./docs/output/. This limits adoption and flexibility. INPUT SOURCES - Where meeting notes come from: Local files (.txt, .md, .docx), Directory scanning (process all files in a folder), Clipboard/stdin (pipe content directly), URLs (fetch from web/wiki)
candidates.extractedDescription: Implement configurable input sources for Chef to read meeting notes from multiple formats and locations including local files (.txt, .md, .docx), directory scanning, clipboard/stdin, and URLs. This will replace the current hardcoded single text file input limitation.

candidates.title: As a Chef user, I want to configure output destinations so that I can export PBIs to different formats and locations
candidates.rawContext: OUTPUT DESTINATIONS - Where PBIs are exported: Local markdown files (current behavior), JSON files (for tooling integration), YAML files (for GitOps workflows), stdout (for piping to other tools)
candidates.extractedDescription: Implement configurable output destinations for Chef to export PBIs to multiple formats including local markdown files, JSON files for tooling integration, YAML files for GitOps workflows, and stdout for piping to other tools. This will replace the current hardcoded ./docs/output/ limitation.

candidates.title: Create InputConfig and OutputConfig types in @chef/core
candidates.rawContext: Create InputConfig and OutputConfig types in @chef/core
candidates.extractedDescription: Define TypeScript types for InputConfig and OutputConfig in the @chef/core package to support the new configurable I/O system. These types will provide structure for input source and output destination configurations.

candidates.title: Add CLI flags for input format and output directory configuration
candidates.extractedDescription: Implement CLI flags --input-format and --output-dir to allow users to override input and output configurations from the command line for one-off usage scenarios.

candidates.title: As a Chef user, I want config file support so that I can set project defaults without CLI flags
candidates.rawContext: Support config file loading with sensible defaults. Config file (.chefrc.yaml or chef.config.yaml) for project defaults
candidates.extractedDescription: Implement configuration file support using .chefrc.yaml or chef.config.yaml files to allow users to set project-level defaults for input and output configurations, reducing the need for repetitive CLI flags.

candidates.title: As a Chef user, I want environment variable support so that I can configure Chef in CI/CD pipelines
candidates.extractedDescription: Implement environment variable support for Chef configuration to enable seamless integration with CI/CD pipelines and automated workflows where config files or CLI flags may not be practical.

candidates.title: Document supported input formats and output destinations
candidates.extractedDescription: Create comprehensive documentation covering all supported input formats (.txt, .md, .docx, directory scanning, clipboard/stdin, URLs) and output destinations (markdown, JSON, YAML, stdout) including usage examples and configuration options.

dependencies.reason: Input source configuration needs the InputConfig type definition to be implemented
Output destination configuration needs the OutputConfig type definition to be implemented
CLI flags for input format require the input source configuration system to exist
CLI flags for output directory require the output destination configuration system to exist
Config file support needs the input configuration system to be in place
Config file support needs the output configuration system to be in place
Environment variable support needs the input configuration system to be in place
Environment variable support needs the output configuration system to be in place
Documentation requires the input formats to be implemented first
Documentation requires the output destinations to be implemented first
Both are configuration mechanisms that should work together harmoniously
Both are configuration mechanisms that should work together harmoniously
Both are configuration mechanisms that should work together harmoniously

missingElements: Error handling requirements for different input sources
strengths: Clear user story format with role and goal
Comprehensive description of input source types
Good context about current limitations and why change is needed
Specific file formats listed (.txt, .md, .docx)
Well-defined scope replacing hardcoded single file input
concerns: No explicit acceptance criteria provided
Dependency on PBI-003 may block immediate work
URL fetching introduces external dependencies and potential security concerns
Directory scanning could have performance implications for large directories
No mention of validation or error handling for different input sources
recommendations: Add explicit acceptance criteria covering each input source type
Define error handling requirements for invalid files, network failures, and access permissions
Consider breaking into smaller PBIs: one for local files, another for URLs/network sources
Add validation requirements for supported file formats and sizes
Specify performance expectations for directory scanning operations
Include security considerations for URL fetching (allowlists, timeouts, etc.)

missingElements: Performance requirements for different output formats
strengths: Clear user story format with well-defined persona (Chef user)
Comprehensive description covering multiple output formats (markdown, JSON, YAML, stdout)
Good business context explaining the replacement of hardcoded limitation
Type is clearly identified as feature
Raw context provides helpful technical details about current vs desired behavior
Dependency relationship with PBI-003 is well-documented
concerns: Missing explicit acceptance criteria - relies on description for success definition
No mention of error handling or validation requirements
Scope could be large - implementing 4 different output formats in one PBI
No indication of priority or order for implementing different formats
Hard dependency on PBI-003 creates potential blocking risk
recommendations: Add explicit acceptance criteria covering each output format (markdown, JSON, YAML, stdout)
Consider breaking into smaller PBIs - one per output format for better sprint planning
Specify configuration mechanism (CLI flags, config file, environment variables)
Add acceptance criteria for error scenarios (invalid paths, permission issues)
Define backward compatibility requirements for existing ./docs/output/ behavior
Include examples of expected configuration syntax
Add performance criteria if relevant (e.g., large PBI exports)

Dependencies or relationships to other components
Definition of what constitutes 'configurable I/O system'

missingElements: Error handling specifications for invalid inputs
Integration details with existing config system

strengths: Clear user story format with well-defined persona and motivation
Specific file naming conventions provided (.chefrc.yaml or chef.config.yaml)

strengths: Clear, descriptive title that explains the deliverable
